title: Can we make sea water into drinking water? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks Manoj Singhania for A2A The major problem in converting 'Sea/Ocean water' into 'Potable Drinking water' is the economy.Exiting methods of Desalination: RO (Reverse osmosis) — Uses costly Membrane Technology;Distillation (Evaporation followed by condensation) — highly energy intensive.Most of large-scale desalination plants generally use RO technique. But, Distillation is widely used on ships for making potable water.  Reverse Osmosis is just a water filtration process which employs a semi-permeable membrane as filter. In this process, oceanic water is pressurized (Pressure > Osmotic Pressure) and is passed through the membrane. Water molecules pass the membrane, but salt and other dissolved solids doesn't. The major obstacles for using RO process are — Membrane inffluent (i.e, sea water) should have steady flow, Membranes are very costly (that is why RO process is not used on trading ships).  Distillation is evaporation of salty sea water and then condensing the vapor back to liquid state. Evaporation can be done in two ways: Evaporation by Boiling and Flash Evaporation. Now, The Boiling process is further divided, on the basis of condenser's structure — into two following types: (1) Tube type; (2) Plate type. → Further research on desalination can help economize the process Hope this helps. Upvote to appreciate

By many various ways (see Wikipedia summary below).  The process is called desalination and is used in many places around the world. It's still expensive, but became much more affordable in recent decade. Estimated cost of desalination of 1000 liters of water is less than 1 Euro (no current reference).   DistillationMulti-stage flash distillation (MSF)Multiple-effect distillation (MED|ME)Vapor-compression (VC)Ion exchangeMembrane processesElectrodialysis reversal (EDR)Reverse osmosis (RO)Nanofiltration (NF)Membrane distillation (MD)Freezing desalinationGeothermal desalinationSolar desalinationSolar humidification-Dehumidification (HDH)Multiple-effect humidification (MEH)Methane hydrate crystallizationHigh grade water recyclingSeawater greenhouse

Yes we can. The process is called desalination. Seawater is drawn from the ocean through intake pipes set out in the open ocean or below the seafloor. That water is filtered for bigger contaminants (and some essential tiny sea creatures) before it is sent through a reverse osmosis system that pressurizes the water through membranes, separating out the salt. Now it is perfect for drinking. However the resulting water lacks the essential minerals which are usually present in natural drinking water. So minerals are added to this to make it better.

This process has beenknown and used for probably thousands of years. “Desalination/distillation is one of mankind's earliest forms of water treatment, and it is still a popular treatment solution throughout the world today. In ancient times, many civilizations used this process on their ships to convert sea water into drinking water. Today, desalination plants are used to convert sea water to drinking water on ships and in many arid regions of the world, and to treat water in other areas that is fouled by natural and unnatural contaminants. Distillation is perhaps the one water treatment technology that most completely reduces the widest range of drinking water contaminants.” Thank you Google

Yep. A lot of the water you drink was once sea water, but evaporation (from the Sun shining on the sea) made it into clouds from which water rained down on the earth as “clean” water. In addition we are doing right near my house (well some miles away, but not that far) at the Carlsbad Desalination Plant - 50 Million gallons a day. Carlsbad Desal Plant <<= link to the plant for more information. Places all over the world do it. Atomic subs and aircraft carriers do it too. Some other ships also can make water by using the steam from the boilers or “waste” heat from the heat exchangers to evaporate the salt water into “fresh” water.

Remove the salt from the water. This can be done in one of three ways. 1 Remove frozen sea ice and thaw it out. It will be fresh. You can do this yorself by freezing Salt water. Not in an ice cube tray but in a bowl where liquid water is left under the ice that is where the salt will end up. In ice cubes it will be concentrated in the center of the ice cube. 2 You can evaporate (boil) sea water collect the steam and condense it back into fresh water. 3 you can run the salt water through a reverse osmosis filtration system . the membrane filter is to fine for the salt molecule to pass through but the water molecule will pass through the membrane giving you fresh pure water.

Watch this video on how to easily convert seawater into drinking water. It turns out that less than one-half of 1 percent of it is drinkable. Out of the rest, 98 percent is oceanic salt water and 1.5 percent remains locked up in icecaps and glaciers. The stark irony of Samuel Coleridge's immortal line "Water, water, everywhere / Nor any drop to drink" is manifest each year in coastal disasters around the world, like Hurricane Katrina, the 2004 Indonesian tsunami and the 2010 Haiti earthquake, as people within sight of entire oceans are threatened with dehydration.

Yes, ocean water can be drinkable. In fact, it is drinkable to some extent in the current day. One cannot drink ocean water directly. This is due to the fact that there is too much salt dissolved in it. That much salt can be very dangerous for our body. Some countries have started to install large desalination plants near the oceans to purify the water. What desalination does is remove the excess of salt from the water. The issue is desalination is a very costly process and requires a lot of energy to desalinate 1 liter of water. So, although ocean water can be drinkable in present day situation it is very costly. In the future, we might be able to reduce the amount of energy required for desalination or come up with another method to purify ocean water. So, yes, ocean water can be drinkable. Blue Mount Alkaline RO Water purifier is India’s first Alkaline RO water purifier with LED display and is a leading brand as it has a wide range of water purifiers that help you to drink healthy and safe water which can help you to boost your health and make you more healthy and fit. The water purifiers remove the acid components from the water and make the water more pure and safe to drink. So, switch your drinking habits to Alkaline Water.

The "simple" hurdle that must be overcome to turn seawater into freshwater is to remove the dissolved salt in seawater. That may seem as easy as just boiling some seawater in a pan, capturing the steam and condensing it back into the water (distillation). Water is life and no one can survive without water. Although the percentage of water on earth is more than the land, most of it is salty water and only a certain percentage consists of fresh, drinking water. But due to rising global warming, the seawater level is rising and it is getting mixed with freshwater causing its quantity to decrease. This video will tell you what will happen if seawater if totally mixed with drinking water.

Not only CAN be turned, but IS turned into drinking water by the billions of gallons per day. Essentially all the fresh water in Saudi Arabia was once sea water and a large fraction of the water in Israel is the result of desalination. Even Southern California practices desal to an extent greater than imagined (do a search for the exact quantity).

Yes. Most ocean-going vessels do this all the time. Even small sail-boat going off-shore for a few days will have a desalination device. These work by reverse-osmosis and are pretty small/compact and cost around a couple thousand for a unit for a small ocean-going boat. This one by Spectra Water Makers makes up to 568 liters/day, runs off 12V and consumes 4.5 Watts/liter.  They also make more portable/life-raft scale systems that you pump by hand.

Desalination is done by nature - sunlight and wind - to evaporate huge quantities of sea water into water vapour that rains down on land (and sea) - the rain on the land recharges rivers and lakes and also the ground water…. If we want to do the same, we need to spend lot of energy and money - we can boil the sea water and collect the distilled water or we can use Reverse Osmosis, to separate salt from the sea water…. Both technologies are well proven but are expensive and energy intensive….but are used to provide drinking water or process water where the local supplies are inadequate…

Yes, if you get rid of the salt by distillation or reverse osmosis . Reverse Osmosis is the least expensive way . There are Reverse Osmosis (R/O) plants ranging in size from those that produce a few pints at a time to those that can supply hundreds or even many thousands of gallons a day and can supply a small town.

most of the middle east countries have very less rainfall So they desalinate sea water and use for all purpose. There are two methods 1 multi stage flash evoperation 2 reverse osmosis. there are many ways to desalinate salt water, some low tech and some tech intensive. Desalination - Wikipedia

Yes, through the reverse osmosis process forcing the see water through a membrane that ensures separation of dissolved salt and impurities. It is potable, though can’be said as 100% pure. The process is slow and costly, but can be improved further through research.
By the use of a reverse osmosis desalination plant would be one way. Another is to create a solar still and drink the condensation. Solar still - Wikipedia

Nuclear submarines, which are capable of remaining underwater for months at a time, could never carry sufficient fresh water in tanks for a lengthy submersion. So they make their own fresh water. So, I think, do aircraft carriers. Since the only source of water for those two types of vessels is the ocean, it seems like it works pretty well.

Take the salt out. It's called desalination. There are a few options, commercially the most common is reverse osmosis. If you need to know how that works look it up on Wikipedia. Or you could heat the salt water, catch the steam amd turn that into fresh water since salt will stay behind. That would be distillation.
Yes you can. There is a few ways but if it only for your peronal use while walking along the beach you can buy a revearse osmosis and you need to pump 5 lts of water to get 1 lt of drinking water

The "simple" hurdle that must be overcome to turn seawater into fresh water is to remove the dissolved salt in seawater. That may seem as easy as just boiling some seawater in a pan, capturing the steam and condensing it back into water

Yes, desalination is used in many arid countries including Israel, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Kuwait and others. Traditionally it has been quite energy intensive using thermal distillation but new more efficient processes such as reverse osmosis have been introduced in recent years. Manufacturers range from GE which makes complete skid mounted systems to many smaller firms. Like electriciy, conservation goes a long way. The correct economic analysis weighs the cost of desalination against the lowest value uses of water which could be addressed in a different way. This approach gives the opportunity cost of the low value uses. Saving 1000 gallons / month by using a sub-soil watering system on a new lawn installation trades against the alternative of a costly ($ and kilowatts) desalination system. If there is another way, desalination should be avoided.
Yes. https://water.usgs.gov/edu/drinkseawater.html

Yes, it is possible. Many countries does it. Either you distil the sea water like Saudi Arabia does or you pass the water through reverse osmosis process like most others and you get clean drinking water.

Principal methods in use today are: (1) Reverse osmosis - Water is passed though a membrane whose porosity will not allow salts to pass, but will pass water molecules. This membrane needs to be back-flushed periodically to clear the accumulated salts from it. (2) Distillation - Boil the water and collect the steam.
With massive amounts of energy and reverse osmosis or even more energy and distillation then the water part can be separated from the salty part and presto drinking water. It cannot be MacGivered.

Yes, desalinization removes the salt from sea water and renders it potable. There are countries doing this today for drinking water, for example Israel. The US Navy uses desalinization for drinking water on ships as well.

By passing the sea water through a semi permeable membrane…the sea water will leave the dissolved salts once it crosses the membrane.The process will require the membrane to be washed at regular intervals to get rid of dissolved salts. Another method is through electrolysis of sea water with a more reactive metal than the salt of different metals dissolved in the sea water. It will be costlier than the former option.
